concept.title: Referencing Field Names
concept.shortdesc: To understand references to fields, think of the record as a directory, and the field reference as the path to the field. come back to this - natty's comments

conbody.p: When a record is a line of text, the record acts like root directory with one level of subdirectories. A reference to a field in a text record is simply: /<field name>. So a field named CITY displays as /CITY.

When a record is complex, like a JSON object, the root directory might have a more complex structure. In this case, a reference to a field is the path to the field as follows: /<path to field>/<field name>. So a field in a JSON tweet might display as /users/followers_count.
stuff below is oldStages display a field name with a preceding slash as follows:

After you preview data or select fields using preview data, you can generally select fields from a list. When a list is not available or when you want to define a new field name, type in the field name with a preceding slash.

For example, when you define an output field for an Expression Evaluator, you can select from a list of fields passed from the previous stage. But to create a new field for the results of the expression, you enter a field name, such as /Code.
